00019 /*!
00020  * \file
00021  * \author Russell Bryant <russell@digium.com>
00022  * \brief Generic event system
00023  *
00024  * The purpose of this API is to provide a generic way to share events between
00025  * Asterisk modules.  Code can generate events, and other code can subscribe to
00026  * them.
00027  *
00028  * Events have an associated event type, as well as information elements.  The
00029  * information elements are the meta data that go along with each event.  For
00030  * example, in the case of message waiting indication, the event type is MWI,
00031  * and each MWI event containts at least three information elements: the
00032  * mailbox, the number of new messages, and the number of old messages.
00033  *
00034  * Subscriptions to events consist of an event type and information elements,
00035  * as well.  Subscriptions can be to all events, or a certain subset of events.
00036  * If an event type is provided, only events of that type will be sent to this
00037  * subscriber.  Furthermore, if information elements are supplied with the
00038  * subscription, only events that contain the specified information elements
00039  * with specified values will be sent to the subscriber.  For example, when a
00040  * SIP phone subscribes to MWI for mailbox 1234, then chan_sip can subscribe
00041  * to internal Asterisk MWI events with the MAILBOX information element with
00042  * a value of "1234".
00043  *
00044  * Another key feature of this event system is the ability to cache events.
00045  * It is useful for some types of events to be able to remember the last known
00046  * value.  These are usually events that indicate some kind of state change.
00047  * In the example of MWI, app_voicemail can instruct the event core to cache
00048  * these events based on the mailbox.  So, the last known MWI state of each
00049  * mailbox will be cached, and other modules can retrieve this information
00050  * on demand without having to poll the mailbox directly.
00051  */
00052 
00053 #ifndef AST_EVENT_H
00054 #define AST_EVENT_H
00055 
00056 #include "asterisk/event_defs.h"
00057 
00058 /*! 
00059  * \brief Subscriber event callback type
00060  *
00061  * \param event the event being passed to the subscriber
00062  * \param userdata the data provider in the call to ast_event_subscribe()
00063  *
00064  * \return The event callbacks do not return anything.
00065  */
00066 typedef void (*ast_event_cb_t)(const struct ast_event *event, void *userdata);
00067 
00068 /*! 
00069  * \brief Subscribe to events
00070  *
00071  * \param event_type The type of events to subscribe to
00072  * \param cb The function to be called with events
00073  * \param userdata data to be passed to the event callback
00074  *
00075  * The rest of the arguments to this function specify additional parameters for
00076  * the subscription to filter which events are passed to this subscriber.  The
00077  * arguments must be in sets of:
00078  * \code
00079  *    <enum ast_event_ie_type>, [enum ast_event_ie_pltype, [payload] ]
00080  * \endcode
00081  * and must end with AST_EVENT_IE_END.
00082  *
00083  * If the ie_type specified is *not* AST_EVENT_IE_END, then it must be followed
00084  * by a valid IE payload type.  If the payload type specified is
00085  * AST_EVENT_IE_PLTYPE_EXISTS, then the 3rd argument should not be provided.
00086  * Otherwise, a payload must also be specified.
00087  *
00088  * \return This returns a reference to the subscription for use with
00089  *         un-subscribing later.  If there is a failure in creating the
00090  *         subscription, NULL will be returned.
00091  *
00092  * Example usage:
00093  *
00094  * \code
00095  * peer->mwi_event_sub = ast_event_subscribe(AST_EVENT_MWI, mwi_event_cb, peer,
00096  *     AST_EVENT_IE_MAILBOX, AST_EVENT_IE_PLTYPE_STR, peer->mailbox,
00097  *     AST_EVENT_IE_END);
00098  * \endcode
00099  *
00100  * This creates a subscription to AST_EVENT_MWI events that contain an
00101  * information element, AST_EVENT_IE_MAILBOX, with the same string value
00102  * contained in peer->mailbox.  Also, the event callback will be passed a
00103  * pointer to the peer.
00104  */
00105 struct ast_event_sub *ast_event_subscribe(enum ast_event_type event_type, 
00106    ast_event_cb_t cb, void *userdata, ...);
00107 
00108 /*!
00109  * \brief Un-subscribe from events
00110  *
00111  * \param event_sub This is the reference to the subscription returned by
00112  *        ast_event_subscribe.
00113  * 
00114  * \return Nothing
00115  */
00116 void ast_event_unsubscribe(struct ast_event_sub *event_sub);
00117 
00118 /*!
00119  * \brief Check if subscribers exist
00120  *
00121  * \param event_type This is the type of event that the caller would like to
00122  *        check for subscribers to.
00123  *
00124  * The rest of the arguments to this function specify additional parameters for
00125  * checking for subscriptions to subsets of an event type. The arguments must
00126  * in sets of:
00127  * \code
00128  *    <enum ast_event_ie_type>, [enum ast_event_ie_pltype, [payload] ]
00129  * \endcode
00130  * and must end with AST_EVENT_IE_END.
00131  *
00132  * If the ie_type specified is *not* AST_EVENT_IE_END, then it must be followed
00133  * by a valid IE payload type.  If the payload type specified is
00134  * AST_EVENT_IE_PLTYPE_EXISTS, then the 3rd argument should not be provided.
00135  * Otherwise, a payload must also be specified.
00136  *
00137  * \return This returns one of the values defined in the ast_event_subscriber_res
00138  *         enum which will indicate if subscribers exist that match the given
00139  *         criteria.
00140  *
00141  * Example usage:
00142  *
00143  * \code
00144  * if (ast_event_check_subscriber(AST_EVENT_MWI,
00145  *     AST_EVENT_IE_MAILBOX, AST_EVENT_IE_PLTYPE_STR, mailbox,
00146  *     AST_EVENT_IE_END) == AST_EVENT_SUB_NONE) {
00147  *       return;
00148  * }
00149  * \endcode
00150  *
00151  * This example will check if there are any subscribers to MWI events for the 
00152  * mailbox defined in the "mailbox" variable.
00153  */
00154 enum ast_event_subscriber_res ast_event_check_subscriber(enum ast_event_type event_type, ...);
00155 
00156 /*!
00157  * \brief Report current subscriptions to a subscription subscriber
00158  *
00159  * \arg sub the subscription subscriber
00160  *
00161  * \return nothing
00162  *
00163  * This reports all of the current subscribers to a subscriber of
00164  * subscribers to a specific event type.  (Try saying that a few times fast).
00165  *
00166  * The idea here is that it is sometimes very useful for a module to know when
00167  * someone subscribes to events.  However, when they first subscribe, this
00168  * provides that module the ability to request the event core report to them
00169  * all of the subscriptions to that event type that already exist.
00170  */
00171 void ast_event_report_subs(const struct ast_event_sub *sub);
00172 
00173 /*!
00174  * \brief Create a new event
00175  *
00176  * \param event_type The type of event to create
00177  *
00178  * The rest of the arguments to this function specify information elements to
00179  * add to the event.  They are specified in the form:
00180  * \code
00181  *    <enum ast_event_ie_type>, [enum ast_event_ie_pltype, [payload] ]
00182  * \endcode
00183  * and must end with AST_EVENT_IE_END.
00184  *
00185  * If the ie_type specified is *not* AST_EVENT_IE_END, then it must be followed
00186  * by a valid IE payload type.  The payload type, EXISTS, should not be used here
00187  * because it makes no sense to do so.  So, a payload must also be specified
00188  * after the IE payload type.
00189  *
00190  * \return This returns the event that has been created.  If there is an error
00191  *         creating the event, NULL will be returned.
00192  *
00193  * Example usage:
00194  *
00195  * \code
00196  * if (!(event = ast_event_new(AST_EVENT_MWI,
00197  *     AST_EVENT_IE_MAILBOX, AST_EVENT_IE_PLTYPE_STR, mailbox,
00198  *     AST_EVENT_IE_NEWMSGS, AST_EVENT_IE_PLTYPE_UINT, new,
00199  *     AST_EVENT_IE_OLDMSGS, AST_EVENT_IE_PLTYPE_UINT, old,
00200  *     AST_EVENT_IE_END))) {
00201  *       return;
00202  * }
00203  * \code
00204  *
00205  * This creates a MWI event with 3 information elements, a mailbox which is
00206  * a string, and the number of new and old messages, specified as integers.
00207  */
00208 struct ast_event *ast_event_new(enum ast_event_type event_type, ...);
00209 
00210 /*!
00211  * \brief Destroy an event
00212  *
00213  * \param event the event to destroy
00214  *
00215  * \return Nothing
00216  *
00217  * \note Events that have been queued should *not* be destroyed by the code that
00218  *       created the event.  It will be automatically destroyed after being
00219  *       dispatched to the appropriate subscribers.
00220  */
00221 void ast_event_destroy(struct ast_event *event);
00222 
00223 /*!
00224  * \brief Queue an event
00225  *
00226  * \param event the event to be queued
00227  *
00228  * \retval zero success
00229  * \retval non-zero failure
00230  *
00231  * This function queues an event to be dispatched to all of the appropriate
00232  * subscribers.  This function will not block while the event is being
00233  * dispatched because a pool of event dispatching threads handle the event 
00234  * queue.
00235  */
00236 int ast_event_queue(struct ast_event *event);
00237 
00238 /*!
00239  * \brief Queue and cache an event
00240  *
00241  * \param event the event to be queued and cached
00242  *
00243  * The rest of the arguments to this function specify information elements to
00244  * use for determining which events in the cache that this event should replace.
00245  * All events in the cache that match the specified criteria will be removed from
00246  * the cache and then this one will be added.  The arguments are specified in 
00247  * the form:
00248  *
00249  * \code
00250  *    <enum ast_event_ie_type>, [enum ast_event_ie_pltype]
00251  * \endcode
00252  * and must end with AST_EVENT_IE_END.
00253  *
00254  * If the ie_type specified is *not* AST_EVENT_IE_END, then it must be followed
00255  * by a valid IE payload type.  If the payload type given is EXISTS, then all
00256  * events that contain that information element will be removed from the cache.
00257  * Otherwise, all events in the cache that contain an information element with
00258  * the same value as the new event will be removed.
00259  *
00260  * \note If more than one IE parameter is specified, they *all* must match for
00261  *       the event to be removed from the cache.
00262  *
00263  * Example usage:
00264  *
00265  * \code
00266  * ast_event_queue_and_cache(event,
00267  *     AST_EVENT_IE_MAILBOX, AST_EVENT_IE_PLTYPE_STR,
00268  *     AST_EVENT_IE_END);
00269  * \endcode
00270  *
00271  * This example queues and caches an event.  Any events in the cache that have
00272  * the same MAILBOX information element as this event will be removed.
00273  *
00274  * The purpose of caching events is so that the core can retain the last known
00275  * information for events that represent some sort of state.  That way, when
00276  * code needs to find out the current state, it can query the cache.
00277  */
00278 int ast_event_queue_and_cache(struct ast_event *event, ...);
00279 
00280 /*!
00281  * \brief Retrieve an event from the cache
00282  *
00283  * \param event_type The type of event to retrieve from the cache
00284  *
00285  * The rest of the arguments to this function specify information elements to
00286  * match for retrieving events from the cache.  They are specified in the form:
00287  * \code
00288  *    <enum ast_event_ie_type>, [enum ast_event_ie_pltype, [payload] ]
00289  * \endcode
00290  * and must end with AST_EVENT_IE_END.
00291  *
00292  * If the ie_type specified is *not* AST_EVENT_IE_END, then it must be followed
00293  * by a valid IE payload type.  If the payload type specified is
00294  * AST_EVENT_IE_PLTYPE_EXISTS, then the 3rd argument should not be provided.
00295  * Otherwise, a payload must also be specified.
00296  *
00297  * \return A reference to an event retrieved from the cache.  If no event was
00298  *         found that matches the specified criteria, then NULL will be returned.
00299  *
00300  * \note If more than one event in the cache matches the specified criteria, only
00301  *       one will be returned, and it is undefined which one it will be.
00302  *
00303  * \note The caller of this function *must* call ast_event_destroy() on the
00304  *       returned event after it is done using it.
00305  *
00306  * Example Usage:
00307  *
00308  * \code
00309  * event = ast_event_get_cached(AST_EVENT_MWI,
00310  *     AST_EVENT_IE_MAILBOX, AST_EVENT_IE_PLTYPE_STR, mailbox,
00311  *     AST_EVENT_IE_END);
00312  * \endcode
00313  *
00314  * This example will check for an MWI event in the cache that matches the
00315  * specified mailbox.  This would be the way to find out the last known state
00316  * of a mailbox without having to poll the mailbox directly.
00317  */
00318 struct ast_event *ast_event_get_cached(enum ast_event_type, ...);
00319 
00320 /*!
00321  * \brief Append an information element that has a string payload
00322  *
00323  * \param event the event that the IE will be appended to
00324  * \param ie_type the type of IE to append
00325  * \param str The string for the payload of the IE
00326  *
00327  * \retval 0 success
00328  * \retval -1 failure
00329  *
00330  * The pointer to the event will get updated with the new location for the event
00331  * that now contains the appended information element.  If the re-allocation of
00332  * the memory for this event fails, it will be set to NULL.
00333  */
00334 int ast_event_append_ie_str(struct ast_event **event, enum ast_event_ie_type ie_type,
00335    const char *str);
00336 
00337 /*!
00338  * \brief Append an information element that has an integer payload
00339  *
00340  * \param event the event that the IE will be appended to
00341  * \param ie_type the type of IE to append
00342  * \param data The integer for the payload of the IE
00343  *
00344  * \retval 0 success
00345  * \retval -1 failure
00346  *
00347  * The pointer to the event will get updated with the new location for the event
00348  * that now contains the appended information element.  If the re-allocation of
00349  * the memory for this event fails, it will be set to NULL.
00350  */
00351 int ast_event_append_ie_uint(struct ast_event **event, enum ast_event_ie_type ie_type,
00352    uint32_t data);
00353 
00354 /*!
00355  * \brief Append an information element that has a raw payload
00356  *
00357  * \param event the event that the IE will be appended to
00358  * \param ie_type the type of IE to append
00359  * \param data A pointer to the raw data for the payload of the IE
00360  * \param data_len The amount of data to copy into the payload
00361  *
00362  * \retval 0 success
00363  * \retval -1 failure
00364  *
00365  * The pointer to the event will get updated with the new location for the event
00366  * that now contains the appended information element.  If the re-allocation of
00367  * the memory for this event fails, it will be set to NULL.
00368  */
00369 int ast_event_append_ie_raw(struct ast_event **event, enum ast_event_ie_type ie_type,
00370    const void *data, size_t data_len);
00371 
00372 /*!
00373  * \brief Get the value of an information element that has an integer payload
00374  *
00375  * \param event The event to get the IE from
00376  * \param ie_type the type of information element to retrieve
00377  * 
00378  * \return This returns the payload of the information element with the given type.
00379  *         However, an IE with a payload of 0, and the case where no IE is found
00380  *         yield the same return value.
00381  */
00382 uint32_t ast_event_get_ie_uint(const struct ast_event *event, enum ast_event_ie_type ie_type);
00383 
00384 /*!
00385  * \brief Get the value of an information element that has a string payload
00386  *
00387  * \param event The event to get the IE from
00388  * \param ie_type the type of information element to retrieve
00389  * 
00390  * \return This returns the payload of the information element with the given type.
00391  *         If the information element isn't found, NULL will be returned.
00392  */
00393 const char *ast_event_get_ie_str(const struct ast_event *event, enum ast_event_ie_type ie_type);
00394 
00395 /*!
00396  * \brief Get the value of an information element that has a raw payload
00397  *
00398  * \param event The event to get the IE from
00399  * \param ie_type the type of information element to retrieve
00400  * 
00401  * \return This returns the payload of the information element with the given type.
00402  *         If the information element isn't found, NULL will be returned.
00403  */
00404 const void *ast_event_get_ie_raw(const struct ast_event *event, enum ast_event_ie_type ie_type);
00405 
00406 /*!
00407  * \brief Get the type for an event
00408  *
00409  * \param event the event to get the type for
00410  *
00411  * \return the event type as represented by one of the values in the
00412  *         ast_event_type enum
00413  */
00414 enum ast_event_type ast_event_get_type(const struct ast_event *event);
00415 
00416 #endif /* AST_EVENT_H */
